awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Edible, water soluble corn zein films for shelf life extension and improved safety of perishable foods
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this SBIR Phase 1 project will be in significant reduction of food waste.  Food waste is a critically important global challenge. Approximately 30% of food produced for human consumption around the world is either lost or wasted each year – more than enough to feed the hungry.  It is estimated that food loss and waste also contribute 8% of the total global greenhouse gas emissions. The methods used to reduce waste by extending shelf life are not only ineffective, but they also exacerbate other global problems, such as adversely impacting the environment through extensive use of plastic packaging. The proposed solution uses non-GMO corn to create new edible coatings that will reduce food waste by doubling the shelf life of whole and cut fresh fruits and vegetables, enabling greater access to fresh foods for all communities and improving the environmental impact of food waste. 

The proposed project will advance translation for a process using corn zein, considered a water insoluble protein and therefore prohibitively expensive to functionalize in food production. This has prevented its use in food coatings. This project advances translation of a relatively simple process to convert commercial grade zein to a readily water-soluble formulation. The project will develop an effective edible food coating that incorporates other plant-based ingredients, such as fatty acids and plasticizers, to create a hybrid protein/lipid film that (1) exhibits excellent gas barrier as well as moisture barrier properties and extends the shelf life of many under-served commodities; (2) can be generated at reasonable cost; and (3) can be delivered in a single application on existing food processing equipment. The R&D plan will target coatings for a variety of fresh produce that allows comparison with competitive coatings where possible, and provides new coating options where few options are available.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Food loss and waste, which on a global scale, amounts to nearly 1.6 billion tons at a value of nearly $1.2 trillion annually, is an issue that affects everyone, some more directly than others. For wealthy consumers, consequence may be limited to higher food costs due to food spoilage post purchase, while for others food supply chain failures often result in food scarcity. The percentages in the Figure indicate the many,  but disparate,   areas for improvement in food supply chains all around the world. For every sector and in every situation, increasing the shelf life of food can only help.  End of shelf-life is a primary factor of food loss and waste.

Our main goal is to extend the shelf life of perishable foods with an edible coating that regulates the rate of both transpiration to slow moisture loss and respiration to delay ripening. We are reaching this goal with formulations that use only natural and sustainably sourced ingredients. Akorn clean label coatings are also being formulated to deliver such quality objectives as controlling human pathogens, retarding rot and mold, imparting a natural finish, and delivering nutrients and flavors. Our innovation includes a process that renders corn zein, a corn-derived protein and by-product of the corn milling process, water dispersible at concentrations higher than ever achieved before. This allows our coating to deliver functionalities far beyond the lipid-based waxes currently in use, which are applied primarily to control moisture loss and add gloss. 

At the conclusion of our Phase I investigations, we have arrived at a production method with repeatable results for the foundational ingredient, and our team has significantly de-risked the technology and advanced the development of the envisioned coatings by meeting the following objectives: 1) Based on the initial concept, we created stable zein colloids that employ only edible plant-based ingredients that meet most global food regulations. (2) We were able to combine these colloids with plant-based sustainably sourced waxes to create coating formulations. (3) We demonstrated that when applied to the surface of several types of fresh produce, our coatings formulation has evolved to dry quickly and produce films that result in significant shelf-life improvement. (4) We demonstrated that these coatings are compatible with existing packhouse equipment, thus presenting very low barriers to adoption. (5) We demonstrated that by introducing natural antimicrobials, our coatings had a significant effect on controlling listeria. (6) We completed the definition of a minimum viable product (MVP) for our target commodities, expected performance, unit cost, preliminary supply chain implementation plan, and regulatory and labeling status.

Successful launch of our products will benefit everyone.  Consumers will benefit by having access to fresher, tastier, and more appealing produce. This enables healthier food choices, especially in currently underserved food deserts in the US. Packers will benefit by being able to offer a high-quality product that will last longer and that can better withstand the rigors of various types of transport. Extended shelf life also extends the market reach of US exports and in any direction in global markets. Growers benefit by being able to hold off harvesting until the crop begins to develop peak flavor.
